content.value: In the last 25 years, exoplanetology has become an integral part of astronomy and astrophysics, rapidly growing in interest and importance.
This chapter discusses the impact and interest of exoplanets in both professional domains and society, including citizen science projects and media interactions.

title: Exoplanet Research: A History of Discovery

content.value: The idea of countless worlds dates back to ancient Greece, evolving into real science in the 20th century with the discovery of the first exoplanets in the 1990s.
This section explores improvements in Doppler measurements from the 1950s to the 1970s that laid the groundwork for future discoveries.
The significance of HD 114762 b in the context of exoplanet discoveries.
Details the discoveries of 51 Peg b, 70 Vir b, and 47 UMa b and their implications for astronomy.

title: PSR B1257+12 and the First Confirmed Planets Beyond the Solar System

content.value: The discovery of PSR B1257+12's planets marked a significant milestone in exoplanet research.
Explains the technique used to detect planets through variations in pulse arrival times.
Details the confirmation of the planets orbiting PSR B1257+12 and their characteristics.
Discusses the history and significance of naming astronomical objects, including exoplanets.
Exoplanets inherit a complex naming system based on their host stars, established by the IAU.
The first exoplanet discovered was PSR B1257+12 b.
Outlines the IAU-sanctioned rules for exoplanet naming, including the hierarchy of suffixes.
